section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: This section introduces the fundamental concepts of variables and data types in Python. You'll learn how to store information in variables and work with different data types including numbers, text, and booleans. By the end, you'll be able to create variables, identify their types, and perform basic operations.
learning_objectives: Define and create variables in Python using appropriate naming conventions
Identify and utilize four primary data types: strings, integers, floats, and booleans
Perform type conversion between compatible data types using built-in functions
Apply the type() function to determine the data type of any variable or value
Demonstrate best practices for variable naming and avoid common syntax errors

lessons.lesson_objective: Create and assign values to variables using proper Python syntax and naming conventions
key_topics: What are variables and why we use them
Valid variable naming rules and conventions
Printing variables with the print() function

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create three variables: name (assign your name as a string), age (assign your age as an integer), and city (assign your city as a string). Print each variable on a separate line using the print() function.
Create a variable called score and assign it the value 100. Print the score. Then reassign score to 95. Print the new score. Finally, reassign it to score + 5 and print the final value.

lessons.lesson_title: Numeric Data Types: Integers and Floats
lessons.lesson_objective: Differentiate between integer and float data types and perform mathematical operations with each
key_topics: Using type() to identify numeric types

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for hourly_wage (float) and hours_per_week (integer). Calculate weekly_pay by multiplying these variables. Print the result along with its data type using type().

Create a variable celsius with a temperature value. Convert it to Fahrenheit using the formula: fahrenheit = (celsius * 9/5) + 32. Print the result as a float. Then convert fahrenheit to an integer using int() and print it again.

Create two integer variables: numerator and denominator (assign any values, denominator not zero). Perform and print results for: regular division (/), floor division (//), and modulus (%). Label each output clearly.

lessons.lesson_objective: Manipulate string data using indexing, slicing, concatenation, and built-in functions
key_topics: String (str) type and creation with quotes

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables first_name and last_name with your name. Use string concatenation to create a full_name variable with a space between names. Print a greeting: 'Hello, [full_name]!' using concatenation. Then print your first initial (first character of first_name) followed by a period.

Create a variable word and assign it a 7+ letter word. Print the first 3 letters, the last 3 letters, and the middle letter (using indexing). Use slicing for the first and last parts, and index for the middle.

Create a variable pattern with a single character like '*'. Use string repetition to print a triangle pattern: first line with 1 character, second line with 2 characters, third line with 3 characters. Use the print() function for each line.

lessons.lesson_title: Boolean Data Type and Type Conversion
lessons.lesson_objective: Evaluate boolean expressions and safely convert variables between different data types
key_topics: Type conversion functions: int(), float(), str()
When conversion fails and how to avoid errors

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables price1 and price2 with different numeric values. Create three boolean variables: is_equal (price1 == price2), is_greater (price1 > price2), and is_less (price1 < price2). Print each boolean variable with a descriptive label.

Create a string variable num_str with value '42'. Convert it to an integer and store in num_int. Convert num_int to a float and store in num_float. Convert num_float back to a string and store in final_str. Print each variable with its type using type().

Use input() to get a user's age as a string. Convert it to an integer. Calculate their age next year by adding 1. Print 'Next year you will be [age_next_year] years old.' where age_next_year is the calculated integer. Ensure proper type conversion.
